chapter.title: Types and Values
chapter.para: This chapter covers the data types and values which can be represented and manipulated in F3.

sect1.title: F3 Data Types
sect1.para: F3 data types, hereafter called F3 types, describe the kinds of values a F3 expression can have. Every F3 variable, function, and expression has a type, most often determined from context. F3 variables can explicitly declare their type; a function can explicitly declare the types of its parameters and the type of its return value. F3 types (with the exception of Void) consist of an element specifier and a cardinality. The element specifier determines what the type holds and the cardinality determines how many of them can be held.

sect2.title: Element Specifier
sect2.para: Element specifiers are classes or function signatures. Classes include both F3 classes and Java classes. These are some example representations of element specifiers which are classes:

A function signature consists of the parameter types and return type -- function signatures are unnamed and are not tied to particular functions which might implement the signature. These are some example representations of element specifiers which are function signatures:
See Function Types for more information.
All element specifiers are subtypes of java.lang.Object.
[In formal type systems the element specifier would be called the ground type]

sect2.title: Cardinality
sect2.para: The cardinality of a type determines how many elements can be held in a F3 type. The three cardinalities are optional, required, and sequence.

sect3.title: Cardinality: Optional (0 or 1)
sect3.para: Optional cardinality means there can be one element or no elements. This is the cardinality associated with most types, currently including all user defined classes. If you define a class Foo, then the F3 type "Foo" has class Foo as its element specifier and optional as its cardinality. For example:
Says that x can hold an instance of Foo (one element) or can hold null, the nonexistent value (no elements).

sect3.title: Cardinality: Required (1)
sect3.para: Required cardinality means there must be one element. This is the cardinality associated with the built-in types String, Integer, Number, Boolean, and Duration. For example:
Says that k holds one Integer.

The nonexistent value, null, is not a permitted value for types with required cardinality. Attempts to assign null to a type with required cardinality will be converted to the default value (see the Default Values section). Attempts to convert null to a type with required cardinality will be converted to the default value.

sect3.title: Cardinality: Sequence (0-n)
sect3.para: Sequence cardinality means there can be any number of elements, including zero. This is the cardinality associated with explicitly declared sequences. For example:
Says that seq can hold any number of Integers.

sect1.title: Default Values
sect1.para: Each F3 type has an associated default value. The default variable is the value of a variable before it is set. It is also the value of an expression of that type if an error is encountered. For types with optional cardinality their default value is null. For example:
Will print null since x has not been set.
For types with sequence cardinality their default value is the empty sequence of their element specifier. For example:
Will print zero as the size of seq since seq has not been set and its initial value will be an empty sequence of Integer.
Each required type has its own default value, as shown in the Type Chart.
Will print zero since k has not been set and the default value for Integer is 0.

sect1.title: Value Types
sect1.para: Some types are value types. Value types have the following characteristics:

listitem.simpara: they are immutable -- they do not have internal state that can be changed (for example, you can't change the characters in a String)
they have required cardinality (and thus are subclasses of java.lang.Object)
they have a default value different from null

sect1.para: Currently, the only value types are String, Integer, Number, Boolean, and Duration. These types have built-in support in the language:

listitem.simpara: they have a built-in literal format
they, with the exception of Duration, have built-in operations that return values of the type

sect1.para: String, Integer, Number, Boolean, and Duration are discussed in this section.

sect2.title: String
sect2.para: String represents character strings. The default value for the String type is the empty string ("").

sect3.title: Localization of String Literal
sect3.para: When an application displays some text to a user, you'd like the text to be in the user's own language. "Localization" is a mechanism to be able to replace a string literal by a translation selected at run-time.

If a double hash sign ## is prefixed to a string literal, F3 substitutes the string literal with a localized one at run-time, if F3 finds appropriate localization in F3 properties files on the classpath. A F3 properties file contains localized strings for a locale as "key" = "value" pairs. Localized strings are searched using the original string literals as keys. If no localized string is found, the original string literal is used as a default. Optionally, explicit keys can be specified with square brackets ([]). For example:
Suppose this script is Foo.f3, and there is a F3 properties file for French Foo_fr.f3properties, which contains the following localization:
sect3.programlisting: "Monday" = "Lundi" "ABOUT" = "F3 est un langage de script cool !"
sect3.para: The script will print:
sect3.screen: Lundi F3 est un langage de script cool !
sect3.para:
in French locale. You can also provide layered properties files for finer grained control. For example, you can provide localized texts that are France specific in Foo_fr_FR.f3properties, and keep other French localized texts that are country independent in Foo_fr.f3properties. Then the F3 searches the appropriate localized texts by attempting the following fallback search in French France (fr_FR) locale: Foo_fr_FR.f3properties Foo_fr.f3properties (original string)
For more information on the locale and how the F3 properties file is located, refer to java.util.Locale and java.util.ResourceBundle classes of the Java platform.
The encoding of a F3 properties file is UTF-8. Other encodings can be specified with the @charset directive. For example:

is specified in the first line of the F3 properties file, the file is read in ISO-8859-1 encoding. If the string literal contains string-expressions, corresponding properties should only contain the FORMAT_STRING_LITERAL parts of the string expressions, without curly braces and expression parts. For example: def gCal = new GregorianCalendar(1995, Calendar.MAY, 23); def bday = ##"The birthday of Duke is {%1$tB gCal} {%2$te gCal}, {%3$tY gCal}."; Then a F3 properties file that contains the localized text for "bday" should look like (e.g., for French): "The birthday of Duke is %1$tB %2$te, %3$tY." = "L'anniversaire du duc est le %2$te %1$tB %3$tY." Note that the position of those FORMAT_STRING_LITERAL parts (indicated by [argument_index]$) may change in localized texts.

sect2.para: The Integer type represents integers in the range -2147483648 to 2147483647, inclusive. The default value for the Integer type is zero (0).

sect3.title: Integer Literal Syntax.
sect3.para: Integers may be represented in decimal, octal, or hexidecimal formats. Decimal format is the digit 1 through 9 followed by digits in the range 0 through 9, or simply 0 by itself. Octal format is the digit 0 followed by digits in the range 0 through 7. Hexidecimal format is the digit 0 following by 'x' or 'X' then followed by digits in the range 0 through 9 or A through F (upper or lower case). These are all valid Integer literals:

sect3.title: Operations over Integer
sect3.para: Arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, and mod) operate over and return Integer. Comparison operators (==, <, >=, etc) operate over Integer. The sizeof operator returns Integer.

sect3.para: Arithmetic operators (+, -, *, and /) operate over and return Number. The comparison operators (==, <, >=, etc) operate over Number.

sect2.para: Boolean represents the values true and false.

sect3.title: Operations over Boolean
sect3.para: The not, and, and or operators operate over and return Boolean. The comparison operators (==, <, >=, etc) return Boolean. The if-expression and while-expression take Boolean as their condition.

sect1.title: Function Types
sect1.para: A function type represents the set of function definitions with a given signature -- that is, the functions which have the given parameter types and return type.
For example, the variable myFunc is declared as being of a function type:
The variable myFunc can hold function definitions which take an Object and an Integer as parameters and returns a String.
Function types have null as their default value. So, myFunc is initially null, we can give it a value by assignment or initialization. This would be a valid assignment to myFunc:
sect1.programlisting: myFunc = function(obj : Object, k : Integer) { "Here is the Object: {obj}, and the Integer: {k}" }
sect1.para: The function definition currently held in myFunc can be called like any other function:
Which would print:
sect1.screen: Here is the Object: 4000.0ms, and the Integer: 777 Here is the Object: null, and the Integer: 1234
sect1.para: The variable, of course, can be reassigned to any function with those parameters and return type:

sect1.para: Sequences hold a sequence of Object values. Said another way, they have sequence cardinality and any Object as the element specifier.

sect1.title: Void Type
sect1.para: Void type is an odd duck that is only used to indicate that an expression does not have a value. Examples of expressions of Void type are the while-expression and calls to functions which have no return value.
